She is no stranger to travel, having played with the Matildas since 2012, making 70 appearances for her country and representing them in the 2019 FIFA Womenâ€™s World Cup and 2020 Tokyo Olympics. These achievements are made even more impressive given Raso suffered a traumatic back fracture in 2018, after which she was told there was no guarantee she would walk again.
On the domestic stage, the 29-year-old winger spent five years playing in the National Womenâ€™s Soccer League (NWSL); two years at Washington Spirit and three years with the Portland Thorns. Raso, who made 80 appearances in the NWSL, recalled feeling well-suited to the leagueâ€™s athleticism but decided to move to Everton in 2020 and, later, Manchester City in 2021, to develop the technical aspects of her game in the burgeoning Womenâ€™s Super League (WSL).

She meets The Athletic in her final few weeks at City to take us through video clips of her best goals and skills; The Athletic has picked some and Raso others.
In person, she is softly spoken but businesslike, with an understated air of coolness about her. She has a handful of piercings in each ear, wears bracelets she makes herself from a kit she ordered on Amazon â€” a friend spotted the box one day and now she is tasked with making them for everyone â€” and has a quiet confidence. â€œItâ€™s about knowing whether to stay wide or to cut across the line and run in,â€ Raso explains. â€œBeing able to run in off the line like this just sends you closer to goal. I quite liked the finish on this one, though.

Raso wins back the ball in midfield, plays off Emily van Egmond and gallops into the box ahead of a couple of defenders, shooting towards the near post.

I like the counter-attacking kind of game. In this moment, itâ€™s all about my positioning. Did she do an A?â€™â€ Raso smiles. Theirs is the kind of family to wake up at 2am and 4am to watch her games, to fly across the world a handful of times a season to see her play in person.
